On track The review phase indicates that although MARD has launched a lot of rural infrastructure projects applied technical codes standards regarding rural roads come from MOT However Ministry of Transport has not really touched climate change adaptation in their projects planning codes standards Hence there is a need to improve existing code standards to consider climate resilience for these infrastructures The review phase also revealed that it is not at all simple to insert project recommendations into existing codes standards of MOT since it is not only a long process but also requires interministerial discussions Despite such difficulties some findings and recommendations mentioned in the report Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the rural road infrastructure have contributed to the draft manual of rural transport roads of the MOT The contents inserted into the draft consist of i climate change impacts on rural roads ii the importance of construction of drain structures iii a number of feasible technical measures that can be applied iv a number of pavements that can increase the resilience to climate change and v the importance of bioengineering measures for slope protection This can be seen as a great effort of the project already Besides the project has had similar contribution to the upgrading of two technical standards of MARD namely slope concrete standard and dam safety standard The meetings with the two standard improvement teams have shown their high consensus in increasing the thickness of slope slabs to decrease the oxidation as consequence of extreme weather Project recommendations have been appreciated and captured in the reports of standard improvement teams Regarding the indicator of this outcome to ensure the quality of UNDPs support to MARD the MidTerm Review consultants suggest to change the indicator as of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects Presently consultant teams are working together to develop the manuals which are very coherent with each other vulnerability index and CostsBenefits calculation for instance The methodologies to develop these manuals have been discussed with CPMU and UNDP based on the orientations expectations of the participants in the policy consultation workshop dated 29th May 2015 The expectations are mainly i a policy roadmap for MARD to adapt to climate change including possible technical standards ii climate hazard risk maps and provincial planning based on these maps iii lowcost and bioengineering measures and iv related trainings It is expected that first drafts of the manuals can be available in Quarter III2015

description.narrative: of Technical papers providing guidance on mainstreaming climate change into sectorial planning related to rural infrastructure in northern areas

comment.narrative: na there has not been a guidance paper at project outset
A Technical Guidance Paper on mainstreaming climate change into provincial rural infrastructure planning prepared by the project and circulated by MARD

On track The project successfully completed a comprehensive review of relevant policies that included a series of stakeholder consultations Key findings include that most of MARD policies strategies do not take climate change into consideration and are not detailed enough for application The need to employ propoor and noregret approaches for resilience building were also clearly highlighted The New Rural Development Program Sustainable Poverty Reduction Program and provincial socioeconomic development planning processes were particularly identified as priorities for further analysis and engagement by the project
A policy consultation workshop at Thai Nguyen province on 9 September 2014 was able to solicit inputs from 11 departments institutes from MARD and MONRE and 14 DARDs The meeting further highlighted the continued interest in learning from international experience in bioengineering lowcost measures to support resilience
A comprehensive review of current rural infrastructure planning implementation and maintenance and field missions to discuss with key focal points Government officials and community representatives highlighted a number of issues regarding lowcost measures including bioengineering measures The assessment included review of experience from 27 countries from the Netherlands to Laos with legal frameworks codes and policies and implementation methods for introducing lowcost and bioengineering options
Analysis of the most recent climate change projections for Viet Nam and their potential impacts in the focus regions was also a key element of this work With regards to the analysis of key hazards for the region potential increases in intense and concentrated rainfall and associated landslide risk were highlighted as an issue in climate change projections that was particularly of concern with regards to rural infrastructure Other factors impacting current resilience of infrastructure included poor designs using unqualified materials applying unsuitable technical solutions during construction process and OM The review also recognized the clear need to integrate climate change into existing relevant codes and standards especially C677 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures which has been issued since 1970s This implies that the vulnerability mapping under the project should take into account of abovementioned climate disasters
Key steps were also taken into initiating a review of current economic analysis practices and in starting to look at the economic consequences of climate change losses This work is likely to bolster the success of the project in suggesting appropriate methods tools and procedures for climate proofing investment decisionmaking in the NMP At a higher Provincial level it is likely that a key tool for climate change adaptation investment guidance will continue to be the application of the MCA Multi Criteria Analysis method as illustrated by the application of UNDP Teams integrated VA and Hazard models which adopt an integrated format in common with ICEM CAM methodology As an example work on the VA component has identified marked differences in Vulnerability between NMP provinces and ongoing work on Flood and Landslide Hazard risk is expected to further identify differences between provinces which can assist to pinpoint the urgency and extent of CCA interventions investments

description.narrative: Coverage of Climate risks and vulnerability assessment

comment.narrative: There has not been any climate vulnerability assessment implemented for rural infrastructure in Northern mountain provinces
A climate risks and vulnerability assessment for rural infrastructure done for all 15 northern provinces

On track As reported above the assessment will cover 15 project provinces including Dien Bien Lai Chau Son la Hoa Binh Vinh Phuc Phu Tho Bac Giang Bac Kan Yen Bai Lao Cai Lang Son Cao Bang Thai Nguyen Tuyen Quang and Ha Giang then downscaled to Son La and Backan After the vulnerability assessment methodology approved the contractor sent their teams to all provinces and then all districts of two demonstration provinces as named above Son La and Backan to collect secondary data and interviews for missing data OM data The types of structures under the assessment consist of i rural roads ii river embankments iii weirs iv reservoirs and v main canals that are classified as categorical and continuous The process tracks the following indicators age of works number of communes cut off from main road per year past damages number of secondary structures on road material of road embankment OM ratio of poor households proportion of minorities proportion of working age population community contribution to infrastructure number of site inspection type of construction codes followed number of times of damages number of reservoirs stopped from functioning Weightings are also laid for each kind of these indicatorsResults show a picture of Son La Backan and Ha Giang as the most vulnerable province in terms of risk These results will be further deepened with specific recommendations provided by the project in the remaining time of the year The next step will be to integrate these maps with future climate change projects

Detailed vulnerability maps for at least two northern mountainous provinces a map for each province with evidence that these have been presented and disseminated to at least 50 of Northern Mountain Provinces

On track Fifty percent completed Vulnerability assessment results are nearly completed The CPMU mobilized a firm and an international climate change expert in Quarter III 2014 An international climate change expert supported a national team to finalize the vulnerability assessment methodology introduced at the inception workshop November 2013 A number of meetings with different institutions individuals were held including a vulnerability assessment methodology consultation workshop in October 2014 to help finalize the methodology After data collection and analysis the consultant has submitted a complete database set and vulnerability assessment report to CPMU Results were shared with Government stakeholders from 15 Northern mountain provinces and downscaled to two piloting provinces namely Backan and Sonla This work will be further supported by the development of landslide and flashflood risk maps for the whole region and two provinces and will be completed in 2015 They are expected to provide visual vulnerability results based on different scenarios AR5 IPCC This is a valuable opportunity for GoV to place in the public domain the extent of and the spatial allocation of the likely public expenditures needed for resilience measures and considered a key impact as the baseline does not provide information on spatial variability of risk and vulnerability As such decision makers can recognize the vulnerabilities of their own provinces in comparison with other provinces They may also learn how to cope with climate change from the provinces with same situation but higher coping capacities less vulnerability On the other hand and more importantly they can use these maps as inputs for their rural infrastructurerelated decisions especially medium and longtermed planning Achievements will be shared with Northern mountain provinces through relevant trainings at the end of 2015
